Fig 7 Design of heterogenous catalyst of Cu4/CeO2(111) for high-efficiency CO2 electroreduction: Tetrahedral Cu4 or Planar Cu4? Tanyu Zhou Writing – original draft Project administration Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Wenkai Bao Validation Methodology Investigation Tianliang Feng Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Ziwei Xu Writing – review & editing Supervision Software Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Guiwu Liu Writing – review & editing Software Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Guanjun Qiao Software Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Jiangsu University Zhenjiang 212013 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Based on the density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, we designed a heterogeneous catalyst of Cu4 cluster supported by CeO2(111) surface for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and compared the structural stabilities, electronic properties and the catalytic performance of tetrahedral Cu4 (Td-Cu4) and planar Cu4 (pl-Cu4) supported on. Our results show that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 exhibits higher structural stability and superior CO2RR catalytic performances compared with Td-Cu4@CeO2. However, during the CO2RR with end-on adsorption of CO2, the pl-Cu4 reconstructs to tetrahedral Cu4O structure (Td-Cu4O) by the spontaneous spillover of the lattice oxygen from the CeO2(111) surface. Such dynamic changes of the catalyst structure and composition alter the coordination environment and oxidation states of Cu atoms, further enhancing the catalytic activity and selectivity for CH4 and CH3OH products. In addition, the pl-Cu4@CeO2 also presents high-efficiency catalytic activity for the *CO-*CO coupling in terms of thermodynamics and kinetics. This theoretical study deepens our understanding of how oxide supports determine and change the structure, composition and catalytic activity of supported metal cluster under realistic reaction conditions, and provides new perspectives for the design of cost-effective CO2RR catalysts with high efficiency and selectivity. Graphical abstract The Cu4 clusters (Tetrahedral Cu4 vs Planar Cu4) supported on the surface of CeO2(111) were theoretically explored as high-performance CO2RR catalyst for both C1 and C2 products. The higher oxidation states induced by the dynamic reconstruction from pl-Cu4 to Td-Cu4O under the oxygen spillover during the reaction promise the great increase of the catalytic performance in efficiency and selectivity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Cu cluster CeO2 CO2 reduction Catalyst reconstruction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis commonly depends on catalytically active centers containing metals to promote their chemical reactions [1–3]. The design of high activity catalysts is based on the understanding of the relationship between the catalyst structure and its performance during the reaction process, the so-called structure–property relationship, thus, highly active and selective catalysts can be achieved by optimizing the geometry and electronic structure of the active site [4–7]. In recent years, efforts have been made to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts by controlling their size, atomic coordination, composition, active metal valence, surface, defects and other key factors [8–17]. An important approach is to engineer nanostructured materials with precisely defined atomic structures and customized properties by regulating the composition, the arrangement of metal atoms, and their interactions with the support. Single cluster catalysts (SCCs) consist of metal clusters (atomic number between 2–20) with precise atomic numbers and structures — supported on suitable matrices. When the size and configuration of the loaded metals change, their coordination environment and valence state also change [18,19]. These factors are sometimes more important than the effect of size itself on the rate of a particular reaction or the selectivity of a particular product, since they are directly related to chemisorption properties and reactivity [20]. Some studies have shown that various isomers of clusters have different chemical reactivities and also have mobility adapted to their structures, facilitating the reaction in the most favorable free energy path [21–23]. However, the interactions between metal clusters with different configurations and the support matrix remain to be understood in depth. In addition, there is a significant challenge to improve the catalyst site activity and synthesis non-precious metal SCCs that are superior to precious metals. Currently the copper is a typical non-precious metal that can effectively catalyze the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to produce C2+ products, undergoing complex redox reactions and structural dynamics change under electrochemical conditions [24–26]. Experimental and theoretical calculations have shown that the configuration of metallic Cu catalysts and their oxidation states play a key role in promoting electrocatalytic CO2RR, especially advantageous in terms of promoting the generation of multi-carbon (C2+) products [27–29]. For example, Wang et al. designed g-C3N4-loaded tetrahedral Cu clusters for CO2 reduction and found that the Cu0/Cux+ interface enabled the CC coupling to occur with a lower kinetic barrier, thus effectively promoting the generation of CH3CH2OH [30]. Fan et al. proposed a strategy called oxygen spillover to improve the oxidation state of Cu during CO2RR, which utilizes Sb2O4 as an oxygen donor [31]. And Wang et al. found that the local electron redistribution of Cu and the introduction of oxygen vacancies were promoted by Ce-doped Cu nanoparticles (Ce-Cu NPs), which enhanced the selectivity and activity of the conversion of CO2 to C2H4 [32]. Therefore, combining Cu clusters with metal oxides is an effective way to improve the electronic state of Cu [33]. Due to the strong metal-oxide interaction, the reducible oxides CeO2 is widely used as a catalyst support in many oxygen-related reactions, such as water-gas shift reactions and CO oxidation reactions, because of its special redox properties and structural stability [34–37]. And the oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 varies with the external oxygen content, its electronic properties can be effectively controlled by changing the environmental conditions. The cerium oxide nanocubes, nanorods and nanopolyhedra with controlled morphology can be easily prepared by controlling the synthesis conditions under practical working conditions, in which the three low-index crystalline surfaces, namely, (100), (110) and (111) surfaces, are mostly exposed. These special morphologies of nanostructures and exposed surfaces provide catalyst carriers with large specific surface area, high reactivity and stability for CO2RR [38,39]. Moreover, Javier et al. found that CeO2 (111) is more favorable for CO2RR compared with the other two surfaces due to its higher hydrogenation activity [40]. Recently, Huang et al. found that spraying a layer of Cu atoms on the surface of cerium oxide nanorods has higher selectivity for the generation of acetate [41]. Recently, Li et al. found that Cu clusters consisting of at least three Cu atoms are required to provide sufficient active sites to efficiently facilitate COCO coupling [42]. The source of C2+ activity in Cu SACs was identified as the structural change from single-atom Cu (Cu1) (leaching from the substrate) to Cu clusters/nanoparticles during working condition. The Cu4 cluster, however, is the smallest particle that may exist either in the tetrahedral structure or planar structure on the catalyst support, which have more unknown possibilities in terms of configuration evolution and catalytic activity. In the previous studies, the tetrahedral Cu4 (Td-Cu4) has been explored on the catalyst supports [30,43,44]. The planar Cu4 (pl-Cu4), however, are mainly designed by anchoring in a template scaffold of the organic molecules [45,46]. Indeed, metal-support interaction was proved to enhance the thermal stability and sintering resistance of the catalysts in CO2RR compared with Cu-based catalysts [47,48]. Meanwhile, the higher oxidation states of Cu modulated by the CeO2(111) facet and the its higher hydrogenation activity can provide the sufficient activation sites for the CO2RR and avoid the catalyst poisoning [40]. Up to now, rare attention has been paid to the competition between Td-Cu4 and pl-Cu4 in terms of the structural stability and the catalytic performance on the catalyst support with strong metal-oxide interaction. Their mutual structural transformation during the realistic reaction under the oxygen-rich environment as well as the relevant influence on the catalytic properties is still ambiguous. Herein, based on the density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, we performed a theoretical exploration on the heterogenous structure of Cu4 cluster supported by CeO2(111) surface by considering both the Td-Cu4 and pl-Cu4 as the CO2RR catalyst. Our calculations show that although the pl-Cu4 on the CeO2 has advantages in the structural stability and catalytic performances in catalyzing both the C1 and C2 products, it can evolve to a Td-Cu4O structure accompanied by the spillover of the lattice oxygen atom during the CO2RR, which can largely increase the catalytic efficiency and selectivity due to the dynamic change of the Cu4 structure, composition and the oxidation state. Moreover, the CC coupling for the C2 products via the symmetric *CO + *CO route was confirmed to be both thermodynamically favorable and kinetically feasible on the pl-Cu4@ CeO2(111). 2 Computational method The Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were implemented by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) for all of the structure optimizations and the free energies of the CO2 reduction reaction with the computational details in the supporting information. In order to avoid interactions of the periodic images, a slab of 4 × 4 × 1 cerium oxide supercell loaded Cu4 cluster were adopted. The lattice parameters for pl-Cu4@CeO2 and Td-Cu4@CeO2 are set as a = b = 15.4643 Å, c = 32 Å”, α = β =90°, γ = 120° The k points were set at 2 × 2 × 1 based on Monkhouse meshes, and all atoms in the lattice were relaxed until the result reaches convergence criterion of electron energy of 1 × 10−4 eV and interatomic forces of 0.01 eV/Å. Seven atomic layers were used in all cerium dioxide structures, and the O terminated layer of the CeO2(111) surface is selected due to geometrical matching and strong bonding between the O atoms and the Cu clusters, which can enhance the catalytic activity. For all DFT calculations we considered van der Waals interactions (IVDW = 12). In order to mimic the semi-infinite surface, the bottom two layer were fixed during the DFT calculations. During the CO2RR calculation, the associated adsorption energies (Eads), free energy changes(ΔG) and the limiting potentials (UL) were calculated based on the definitions in the supporting information. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural stability and preliminary screening of CO2RR catalyst According to previous studies, the planar rhombic Cu4 (pl-Cu4) is the ground state structure for the free Cu4 system, rather than the tetrahedral Cu4 (Td-Cu4) or other planar configurations [49]. Our DFT calculations also further demonstrate that Td-Cu4 can spontaneously transform into pl-Cu4 (Fig. S1b). However, as the heterogeneous cluster, the Td-Cu4 were found to be stable supported by the g-C3N4 and could present high catalytic activity in the CO2RR [30]. The planar Cu4, however, are usually be stabilized by the elaborately designed molecular scaffold that anchoring the four Cu atoms [45,46]. Because of the structural differences between Td-Cu4 and pl-Cu4, their different interactions with the CeO2(111) surface result in different valence states of the Cu atoms, which leads to different adsorption energies for key intermediates in the CO2RR process and facilitates different CC coupling reactions [30,46]. Herein, the two isomers of Td-Cu4 and pl-Cu4 are both taken into consideration as the trial configurations on the CeO2(111) surface (Fig. 1a ). Very surprising, both can be stabilized by bonding with the lattice O atoms below. As shown in Fig. 1b, c and d, three atomic sites of CeO2(111) surface are selected to anchor the Cu4: 1) Hexagonal close-packed site (hcp) for tetrahedral Cu4 (Th d-Cu4@CeO2); 2) Face centered cubic site (fcc) for tetrahedral Cu4 (Tf d-Cu4@CeO2); and 3) rhombic site including adjacent hcp and fcc sites for planar Cu4 (pl-Cu4@CeO2). As shown in Fig. S2, after structural optimization, all three structures are geometrically stable on the CeO2(111) surface with total energies of −885.22 eV, −885.30 eV and −885.66 eV, respectively. The total energies of Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2 are very close with the energetic difference of only 0.08 eV. The pl-Cu4@CeO2 has the lower energy indicating its higher stability. Indeed, the stability of the Td-Cu4 and pl-Cu4 originates from the geometric matching between the bonding Cu atoms and the lattice oxygens below (Fig. S2). For Td-Cu4, the three bottom Cu atoms form a triangular geometry that just bonds to the three lattice O atoms at the hcp and fcc sites. However, for the pl-Cu4, the four planar Cu atoms form an asymmetric rhombic structure which bonds to the four rhombic O atoms perfectly. The Cu-Cu bond lengths of asymmetric rhombic planar structure are within 2.400 ∼ 2.448 Å (Fig. S3), which are ∼ 0.2 Å shorter than the ones of the square Cu4 previously reported [35]. And, each Cu atom is bonded to its neighboring O atom with Cu-O bond lengths of 1.810 Å, 1.803 Å, 1.804 Å, and 1.820 Å respectively. In addition, the binding energy of planar Cu4 clusters to the substrate is −9.15 eV, which is stronger than that of tetrahedral Cu4 clusters. Indeed, the strong stability between planar Cu4 clusters and cerium oxide arises from the strong interactions generated by the charge transfer between the bottom four Cu atoms and the substrate O atoms. As shown in Fig. 1e, f and g, according to charge density difference (CDD) and Bader charge calculations, a larger charge aggregation region exists between the four Cu atoms of planar Cu4 clusters and the surface O of CeO2, resulting stronger interactions. The electron localization function (ELF) in the regions of CeO2 surface and Cu4 clusters is about 0.2 (Fig. S4), and this low ELF suggests that the electrons around the Cu atoms are highly susceptible to delocalization and thus interact with the external electrons of O, which verifies the electrons around Cu atoms are prone to delocalize, facilitating interactions with O atoms [50]. In addition, the higher charge transfer leads to the Cu atoms turning into a higher oxidation state of Cu+, which in turn forms a more stable binding state with CeO2. In contrast, only the three bottom Cu atoms of Td-Cu4 have more charge transfer with the CeO2(111) surface, and the top Cu atom has only 0.11 eV and 0.16 eV charge loss at the hcp and fcc sites, respectively. For a preliminary screening, we investigated the CO2 adsorption and the two initial hydrogenation steps, namely, CO2 → *CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH on free pl-Cu4 cluster, CeO2(111) surface and the three different Cu4@CeO2 structures (pl-Cu4@CeO2, Th d-Cu4@CeO2, Tf d-Cu4@CeO2). We initially explored two CO₂ adsorption configurations (side-on and end-on), designating them as CCu bonding and OCu bonding based on their bonding modes. All of the CO2 stabilized adsorption structures as well as the adsorption energies on different considered sites with CCu bonding or OCu bonding are shown in Fig. S5. However, only on the pl-Cu@CeO2, the two adsorption configurations are both stable after the geometry optimizations. For the others, only the adsorptions with OCu bonding are stable. For CO2 adsorption on Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2, two sites were considered: the top Cu and the bottom Cu. The results in Fig. S5 show that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 has stronger CO2 adsorption energies (−1.30 eV and −0.90 eV) while the Td-Cu4@CeO2 and the free pl-Cu4 cluster had weaker ones. The free energy diagram of the CO2 → *HCOOH pathway is shown in Fig. 1h. The first step in CO2 reduction is the hydrogenation of absorbed CO2 to form stable *COOH species, which can react with proton-electron pairs to form HCOOH and H2O. As shown in Fig. 1h, for pure CeO2(111) surface, the potential-determining step (PDS) is *COOH → *HCOOH, which has an uphill free energy change of 2.41 eV. The associated free energy changes are 0.37 eV, 0.18 eV, 0.68 eV and 1.01 eV for free pl-Cu4, pl-Cu4@CeO2, Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2, respectively. Among them, the pl-Cu4@CeO2 has the smallest uphill free energy change of 0.18 eV, which is much smaller than the ones of other selected structures. In addition, it is reported that the Cu0/Cux+ interface of the Td-Cu4 anchored in the g-C3N4 has high CO2 capture capacity at the top Cu and high CO2RR catalytic activity at bottom Cu (Cux+) site. However, in our Td-Cu4@CeO2, we found that the adsorption energy of CO2 on the bottom Cu is very weak (Fig. S5) and also has higher uphill free energy change (0.68 eV on Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and 0.81 eV on Tf d-Cu4@CeO2) in the first hydrogenation process (Fig. S6). Thus, the pl-Cu4@CeO2 catalyst has higher potential as high-efficient CO2RR catalyst. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is usually considered a competitive reaction during CO2RR. Fig. 1i shows the free energies of HER for pure CeO2,pl-Cu4@CeO2, Th d-Cu4@CeO2, and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2. HER occurs on four catalysts with free energy changes of *H adsorption are- 4.41 eV, −3.51 eV, −0.70 eV and −0.69 eV, respectively, indicating that the pure CeO2(111) facets and pl-Cu4@CeO2 have high *H binding energies, resulting in thermodynamic difficulty in the final *H2 production. In contrast, the Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2 catalysts have a moderate adsorption capacity, and this moderate hydrogen adsorption capacity allows for easy generation of *H2 on them. To further evaluate the competitiveness of the CO2RR and HER, the free energies of HER and the difference between the limiting potentials(UL,CO2RR - UL,HER) on the CeO2, pl-Cu4@CeO2 and Th d-Cu4@CeO2 and Tf d-Cu4@CeO2 were calculated in Fig. 1j, where a larger positive value of UL,CO2RR - UL,HER indicates a higher competitiveness of CO2RR over HER [51]. It can be seen that for pl-Cu4@CeO2, the (UL,CO2RR - UL,HER) is 3.44 V, which is much higher than that of pure CeO2(2 V) and Th d-Cu4@CeO2 (0.02 V). Herein, it can be concluded that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 is clearly superior to pure Cu4 clusters, pure CeO2(111) facets and Th d-Cu4@CeO2 in terms of CO2 capture capacity, CO2RR catalytic activity and competitiveness over HER. We will hence focus on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 catalysts in the following investigation. We further studied the structure stability of pl-Cu4@CeO2 and the chemical activation of the CO2 adsorbed on based on the analysis of electronic orbitals and the charge transfer. As shown in Fig. 2a , the density of states (DOS) calculations showed that the 2p orbitals of O hybridized with the 3d orbitals of Cu, suggesting the strong interaction between pl-Cu4 and the bonded O atoms on the CeO2(111) surface. Combined with the charge density distribution in Fig. 1 g, the strong interaction and stability of pl-Cu4@CeO2 originate from the charge transfer and orbital hybridization between the bottom four Cu atoms and the neighboring O atoms. We considered both side-on and end-on for CO2 adsorption on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 catalyst (Fig. S7), also we designating them as CCu bonding and OCu bonding based on their bonding modes. The adsorption energy of the CO2 on pl-Cu4@CeO2 with CCu bonding reaches −1.30 eV, which is stronger than that on pure Cu4 cluster (−0.33 eV). The CO bond lengths were stretched from the original 1.18 Å to 1.28 Å after adsorption, which was elongated ∼ 8 %. At the same time, a bending of the two CO bonds occurred with an angle reaching ∼ 130.676° As shown in Fig. 2b, the CDD indicates that there is a large amount of charge aggregation between the C and Cu atoms, a certain amount of charge transfer between O and the two-terminal Cu atoms. Meanwhile, the Bader charge calculation shows that there is a charge loss of 1.20 e for C atoms and an charge gain of 0.98 e for the O atoms, suggesting the chemical activation of CO bonds. The adsorption energy of CO2 with OCu bonding is −0.90 eV. After optimization of the structural, the O atom at one end of the CO2 molecule is adsorbed on the Cu atomic site. And the CO bond length is broken and the CO2 becomes an asymmetric molecule, which facilitates its activation and further hydrogenation. CDD and Bader charge analysis reveal that the electronic equilibrium between oxygen atoms on both sides of the carbon atom is disrupted. The oxygen atom bonded to the Cu site exhibits a charge accumulation of 1.08 e, exceeding its distal counterpart by 0.1 e. Overall, pl-Cu4@CeO2 inject 0.04 e net charge into CO2, which provides energy for the conversion of CO2 to lower the activation barrier. In this regard, we performed integrated-crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) analyses of two adsorbed CO2 molecules [52]. The smaller negative ICOHP, the weaker the interatomic bonding, implying a higher degree of CO2 activation. As shown in Fig. 2d, e, and f, the ICOHP between the C and O atoms is −5.33 eV before CO2 adsorption, but after CO2 adsorption, the ICOHP of C and O atoms for CCu bonding and OCu bonding are −1.87 eV and −1.83 eV, respectively. Compared with the pristine CO2 molecules, the CO bond strengths are significantly weakened after CO2 adsorption on pl-Cu4@CeO2, indicating that the interaction of CO2 with planar Cu atoms promotes the activation of CO2. 3.2 CO2RR for C1 products 3.2.1 CO2RR with side-on adsorption of CO2 For the CO2RR with side-on adsorption of CO2 (CCu bonding), the free energy pathway of CO2RR and the associated structures are shown in Fig. 3a and b. The first step of CO2RR is the hydrogenation of adsorbed CO2 to form stable *COOH species or *HCOO species. Interestingly, the addition of H to C and O atoms both produces the *COOH intermediate, and the change of free energy is −0.68 eV. In the following step, the *COOH and *H can react with a proton electron pair to form *CO + H2O or *HCOOH. As shown in Fig. 3a, the free energy change of *COOH → *CO and *COOH → *HCOOH is −0.32 eV and 0.18 eV, respectively. Obviously, there are more energy released to produce *CO than the production of *HCOOH, indicating that the production of *CO is more energetically favorable than that of *HCOOH. Subsequently, the hydrogenation of *CO may produce two kinds of reaction intermediates: *COH or *HCO. The free energy change of the production of *COH is 1.71 eV, which is much higher than that of *HCO (0.45 eV). Therefore, the *CO→*HCO path is selected for subsequent calculations. The PDS for the final product of CH3OH and CH4 is *HCO→*CHOH and *CH3→*CH4 with free energy change of 0.54 eV and 0.66 eV, respectively, indicating that the production of *CH3OH is more energetically preferred than *CH4 on pl-Cu4@CeO2. Meanwhile, compared with the pure pl-Cu4 cluster and other studies, our work has lower limiting potential for the production of *CO, *HCOOH and *CH3OH on pl-Cu4@CeO2 catalyst (Fig. S8), but with little advantage for the production of CH4 [44,53–55]. For CO2 adsorption on pl-Cu4@CeO2 with CCu bonding, it has the higher selectivity for the generation of *CO, and the final product of CH3OH is also more energetically favored than CH4. 3.2.2 CO2RR with end-on adsorption of CO2 The free energy pathway of CO2RR with end-on adsorption of CO2 (OCu bonding) is shown in Fig. 4a . Its limiting potential of producing *CH4 is 0.09 V, which is much lower than that with CCu bonding (0.57 V). In particular, the free energy changes of producing *HCOOH and *CH3OH are both downhill, indicating a large increasing of the CO2RR catalytic activity. Very impressively, after the first hydrogenation step, a spontaneous spillover of the lattice oxygen from the CeO2(111) to the pl-Cu4 cluster occurs. With the production of *COOH intermediates, the lattice O atom diffused out to form a tetrahedral Cu4O structure (Td-Cu4O) with the original pl-Cu4 cluster (Fig. S9). Such a self-spillover of lattice oxygen on the metal-oxide supports has been recognized as a significant reason for the dynamic surface reconstructions, structure and composition change of the catalyst particle as well as the associated oxidation states, which may result in higher active sites created and exposed for the chemical reactions [56–58]. As heterogenous catalyst, these dynamic evolutions of the interface structures and the active sites has been gradually recognized as a significant response to the realistic reaction and the environmental conditions due to the strong interface interactions [59]. As shown in Fig. 4b and Fig. S9, the Cu1 atoms are slightly lifted along with CO2 molecules adsorbed on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 surface. The lattice oxygen bonded to Cu1 begins to detach from the CeO2 surface and the pl-Cu4 cluster becomes rough (Fig. S9a). With the first step of CO2 hydrogenation, the Cu1 atom moves further away from the other three Cu atoms with the adsorption of intermediates. The distant Cu1 atom is above the three Cu atoms to form a Cu4 tetrahedral structure, and the top Cu1 atom becomes the adsorption site. At this time, the O atom completely spillover from the surface of CeO2 and bond with the four Cu atoms with the bond lengths of 1.82 Å, 2.00 Å, 1.88 Å, and 1.94 Å, respectively (Fig. S9b). During the process of *COOH→*HCOOH→*HCO, the spillover oxygen atom migrates from the outside of the tetrahedral Cu4 structure to its inside as the system continues to be hydrogenated and protonated, and ultimately forms a tetrahedral Cu4O structure (Td-Cu4O). The bond lengths of Cu-O in the Td-Cu4O structure are 1.85 Å, 1.90 Å, 1.87 Å, and 1.97 Å, respectively (Fig. S9c). Previous studies show that the spillover O atom could spontaneously occur for Cu cluster larger than Cu5 and the structure evolution of the metal cluster from multilayer to monolayer were preferred without the chemical reactions [56,57]. However, in our reaction, such a spillover of lattice oxygen can occur spontaneously in advance when the number of the Cu cluster just reaches four (Cun, n = 4). More interestingly, as shown in Fig. 4e, for the pure Cu clusters with different sizes, namely, Cu4, Cu13 and Cu55, our calculations show that the O atom can only stay at their surfaces of clusters and can never dissolved into their bulk positions. This phenomenon is also consistent with the structures of the spillover O on the supported metal clusters reported previously. However, under the effect of the CeO2 surface and the reaction intermediates, the spillover O diffuses into the interior position of Td-Cu4 as a bulk O atom after the *CHO formation. In another word, there is transition from surface O to bulk doped O atom after the *CHO formation. Finally, the top Cu of the Td-Cu4O is further isolated and the distances between the top Cu and the bottom three Cu atoms are 3.48 Å, 2.48 Å, and 3.63 Å, respectively (Fig. 4d). To further explore the characterization of the Td-Cu4O structure, we calculated the charge density difference and Bader charge transfer in Fig. 4c. The spillover O was found to be at the center of the Cu4 cluster with a charge accumulation of 1.006 e, while the charge losses of the four surrounding Cu atoms were 0.86 e, 0.59 e, 0.58 e and 0.54 e, respectively, which indicated that the equilibrium of electric charge between the four Cu atoms had been broken. After the reconstruction of Cu4 cluster, the Td-Cu4O has higher fractional oxidation state (+0.5) than that of pl-Cu4 due to the change of coordination environment, especially with highly improved d-band center [60]. The amount of charge loss on Cu atoms before and after O spillover was compared in table S2. The charge loss of Cu atom at the top of Cu4O (0.86 e) is higher than those of other three Cu atoms at the bottom (0.29 e), indicating that the spillover oxygen promotes the transition of the top Cu to a higher fractional oxidation state (Cu0.43→Cu0.86). Besides, the distances between the top Cu atom and the three bottom Cu atoms become longer after the formation of the Td-Cu4O with the Cut-Cub bond weakened. Both the higher oxidation state and the isolated geometric position of the top Cu show extremely high degree of isolation, which has been proved to be beneficial for high catalytic activity and selectivity. Atomic degree of isolation describes the extent to which atoms are exposed as the catalyst conformation changes during the reaction. It serves as a descriptor for evaluating the activity of metal atomic sites, where geometrically isolated metal atoms enable efficient and selective catalysis [61]. Indeed, the free energy diagram of CO2RR in Fig. 4a shows that the top Cu atom is an active catalytic site of higher efficiency and higher selectivity for CO2RR. All of the intermediate steps for CH3OH production on Td-Cu4O are downhill process and there is only an small uphill free energy change of only 0.09 eV for the CH4 production. Compared with the former CO2 adsorption with CCu bonding, the catalytic efficiency and selectivity for CH3OH has been greatly increased. Besides, as shown in Fig. 1j, the (UL,CO2RR - UL,HER) on the Td-Cu4O is positive and the associated CO2RR can dominate the reaction over HER. The solvent effect is important to the electrocatalytic CO2RR process. Owning to the large computational cost, we selected a benchmark reaction on the pure pl-Cu4, namely, *CO2 + 2H+ + 2e−→ *HCOOH, to test the change of the free energy pathways by considering the implicit solvent effect [62,63]. The VASPsol software was used to implement implicit solvation models [64,65]. The aqueous solvent in VASPsol was selected based on the default parameters, with its relative permittivity set to be 78.4. As shown in Fig. S10, there is an energy drop of ∼ 0.2–0.4 eV for the whole pathway while the uphill free energy change is only reduced by 0.03 eV. This result provides us a rough reference for us to estimate the correction of the solvent effect to the free energy pathways on the pl-Cu4@CeO2, i.e., the higher catalytic activity could be expected if solvent effect is considered in this study. 3.3 CO2RR for C2 products 3.3.1 COCO coupling to generate C2 products Following the CO adsorption, successful coupling of two C atoms is a vital step for CO to generate C2 products. Our designed structure provides sufficient active sites for simultaneous adsorption of two *CO molecules. In the section of C1 products, we know that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 catalyst has a good ability to generate *CO intermediates. This leads to the high coverage of *CO coverage on the Cu+ atoms, which is beneficial to the CC coupling. For the CO to the C2 product, the reactions are as follows: (1) 2CO + 8H+ + 8e− → C2H4 + 2H2O (2) 2CO + 8H+ + 8e− → C2H5OH + H2O Both reactions are 8-electron processes. The free energy diagram of the reduction pathway for the two *CO coupling is shown in Fig. 5a . Before CC coupling, we considered three dual sites of *CO + *CO adsorption on the pl-Cu4@CeO2. As shown in Fig. S11a, the long-diagonal dual sites, (Cu1 - Cu4), short- diagonal dual sites (Cu2 - Cu3) and neighboring dual sites (Cu1 - Cu2) were selected as the initial adsorption sites of *CO + *CO with the two bonding configurations of CCu bonding and OCu bonding considered. Only the adsorption of *CO + *CO with CCu bonding and OCu bonding at the long-diagonal dual sites are geometrically stable after the structural optimization (Fig. S11b and c). For the *CO + *CO initially at the short- diagonal dual sites and neighboring dual sites, however, they either deviate the original sites or lead to the severe collapse of the pl-Cu4 cluster(Fig. S11d-g). Based on the optimized configuration and total energy considerations, we selected the long-diagonal dual-site adsorption of CO2 as the initial structure for investigating CC coupling processes. The free energy change for *CO + *CO → *COCO is −0.02 eV, indicating that the process of CC coupling is an exothermic step on the pl-Cu4@CeO2. The following step is the protonation process of *COCO + H+ → *COCOH with ultralow uphill free energy change of 0.01 eV. The subsequent three hydrogenation steps after *COCOH on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 are all exothermic processes. The *CHCOH is the key intermediate in determining whether the product is ethanol or ethylene. Our calculation shows that the generation of *CHC intermediate is more energetically favorable than the *CHCHOH because an uphill free energy change of 0.06 eV required for *CHCHOH. Thus, the ethylene is expected to the main product via the *CO + *CO coupling. In order to confirm the kinetical feasibility of this *CO + *CO coupling, the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) calculation has been performed to find the energetic barrier of the reaction and the corresponding transition states. The two adsorption configurations of *CO + *CO on the long diagonal dual sites with CCu bonding and OCu bonding were selected as the starting states. As shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. S12, the two different initial adsorption configurations are quite different in their transition sates and the energetic barriers. For the OCu adsorption, the transition states include the inversion of the OCu bonding to CCu bonding, which is the perquisite for the CC coupling. The energetic barrier is therefore as high as ∼3.82 eV, indicating the kinetic infeasibility of the CC coupling starting from this adsorption. However, for the CCu adsorption, the transition sates include the gradual approaching for the two *CO and the final coupling structure. The distance between the two C atoms changes from 6.49 Å to 3.56 Å in the transition state and finally to 1.47 Å, which means the CC coupling occurs. The energetic barrier for the CC coupling is 0.98 eV, indicating the kinetic feasibility of CC coupling starting from this adsorption. 3.3.2 Asymmetric *CHX-*CO coupling In the latest study, the asymmetric coupling, such as *HCO + *CO and *CHX+*CO(X = 1, 2, or 3) coupling, has been found during CO2RR. It has been reported that CO₂ can be selectively converted to acetic acid through the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway via the asymmetric C ̶ C coupling of *CH3 and *CO intermediates [66]. Recently, Li et al. showed that during catalytic reactions, alkyl groups (*CHX) are able to intercept C1 and C2 intermediates and couple to adsorbed *CO [67]. This unique coupling mechanism enables the final product to shift from hydrocarbons to oxygenates. Therefore, we further explored the asymmetric coupling of *HCO + *CO and *CH + *CO in this paper. Our calculation shows that the *HCO + *CO fails to couple on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 (Fig. S13). Instead, the coupling of *CH + *CO with the free energy pathways and the associated structures shown in Fig. 7 . The *CH + *CO coupling is an exothermic process due to the high chemical activity of the *CH intermediate. After the formation of *CHCO, only the two steps of *CHCO → *CH2CO and *CH3CO →*CH2CO are endothermic processes with the uphill free energy change of 0.23 eV and 0.35 eV, respectively. The free energy changes are both lower than that of former *HCO → *CHOH step(∼ 0.54 eV) in Fig. 3a, which is also the PDS step of the asymmetric coupling process. In this asymmetric CC coupling, the final C2 product is CH3CH2OH. However, the adsorption energy of *CHCO (−1.77 eV) is weaker than that of *COCO (−2.68 eV), indicating that the *COCO is more stable in terms of energy. Furthermore, compared with the *CO, the high chemical instability of *CH as well as its low production rates make this asymmetric coupling less dominant than the symmetric *CO + *CO coupling. 4 Conclusions In summary, based on the specific geometry matching and interface interaction between the metal catalyst and the oxide supports, we have designed the Cu4 cluster supported on CeO2(111) as a promising heterogeneous catalyst for electrocatalytic CO2RR. Our results show that the Cu4 cluster, which can exist only in planar configuration as the free structure, stabilizes on the CeO2(111) surface in both tetrahedral (Td-Cu₄) and planar (pl-Cu₄) configurations with minor energy differences. Preliminary screening results indicates that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 has better CO2RR catalytic potentials thanTd-Cu4@CO2 due to the higher oxidation states (Cux+) of the planar Cu atoms. Detailed free energy profile shows that it has a higher selectivity for CH3OH production than that for CH4. Impressively, during the CO2RR with end-on adsorption of CO2, the pl-Cu4 can reconstruct to Td-Cu4O by the spontaneous lattice oxygen spillover. For the Td-Cu4O, the spillover O atom diffused into the inner position of the tetrahedral Cu4 instead of staying on the cluster surface, unlike in the case of pure copper clusters. As a result, the coordination and oxidation states of the Cu atoms are changed, further improving the catalytic efficiency and selectivity. Besides, the CC coupling for C2 products via the *CO + *CO is proved to be quite favorable thermodynamically and kinetically due to the high generation rates of *CO intermediates on the pl-Cu4@CeO2. The free energy change of the PDS is only 0.01 eV and the kinetic barrier for the *CO + *CO approaching and coupling on the pl-Cu4@CeO2 is approximately 0.98 eV, which proves that they are more competitive than the asymmetric coupling (*CH + *CO). This study not only paves a new path for the rational design of cost-effective, high-efficiency and high-selectivity CO2RR catalysts, but also provides atomic-level insights into how realistic reactions conditions and surface environments dynamically affect catalyst structure, composition, and catalytic properties. coredata.dc:description: Based on the density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, we designed a heterogeneous catalyst of Cu4 cluster supported by CeO2(111) surface for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and compared the structural stabilities, electronic properties and the catalytic performance of tetrahedral Cu4 (Td-Cu4) and planar Cu4 (pl-Cu4) supported on. Our results show that the pl-Cu4@CeO2 exhibits higher structural stability and superior CO2RR catalytic performances compared with Td-Cu4@CeO2. However, during the CO2RR with end-on adsorption of CO2, the pl-Cu4 reconstructs to tetrahedral Cu4O structure (Td-Cu4O) by the spontaneous spillover of the lattice oxygen from the CeO2(111) surface. Such dynamic changes of the catalyst structure and composition alter the coordination environment and oxidation states of Cu atoms, further enhancing the catalytic activity and selectivity for CH4 and CH3OH products. In addition, the pl-Cu4@CeO2 also presents high-efficiency catalytic activity for the *CO-*CO coupling in terms of thermodynamics and kinetics. This theoretical study deepens our understanding of how oxide supports determine and change the structure, composition and catalytic activity of supported metal cluster under realistic reaction conditions, and provides new perspectives for the design of cost-effective CO2RR catalysts with high efficiency and selectivity.

coredata.dc:title: Design of heterogenous catalyst of Cu4/CeO2(111) for high-efficiency CO2 electroreduction: Tetrahedral Cu4 or Planar Cu4?
